newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares reach new highs on boom hopes.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares reach new highs on boom hopes.

text.p: Russian shares reached new highs on Monday as worries about President Boris Yeltsin's health eased and investors gambled that the market would repeat last year's boom in 1997.

The Russian Trading System (RTS) index of 24 leading shares closed at a new record of 262.34, after 251.07 at Friday's close and a previous closing high of 251.49 set on January 13. Turnover was a robust $44.9 million.

Dealers said news that President Boris Yeltsin, in hospital with pneumonia, was in a stable condition had supported prices for some days. But the main factor was the market's performance in 1996 and optimism that the boom would continue.
The Kremlin said later in the day that Yeltsin was leaving hospital on Monday.
The Washington-based International Financial Corp said this month that Russia was the best performing emerging stock market in 1996, giving a 155.9 percent return in dollar terms.

"The stock market is not looking at fundamental problems such as Yeltsin's health as much as before. It is driven by the weight of investment, by money," said Martin Diggle, director of Brunswick in Moscow.
Fund managers were enthusiastic about last year's performance and wanted to increase their stake in Russia, hoping the market would fare even better this year.

"Many ended last year underweighted in Russia, and Russia finally ended up among the top performing markets. They expect Russia to be among these, if not the best, this year," he said. "So they are buying, and supply is not too big."
Dealers said the market was also reassured about the political situation in Russia.

"Thank God, Yeltsin is alive and all attempts to remove him seem to be failing miserably. There is optimism on the market and there are fresh orders," said Oleg Tatkov of Renaissance Capital. "Even the West is calm about it."
"Doctors say Yeltsin is all right in hospital. Everyone is optimistic and neither doctors nor journalists are scaring us with bad news," said Sergei Kosynkin, head of equities at Bank Menatep.
Some dealers said funds were flowing into share markets from the treasury bills market, where rouble yields have fallen to about 30 percent from around 40 percent two months ago.
But Tatkov said most money on the stock market was "fresh".
"The share market and the T-bill market are as separated as they have always been. What we've got here is a wave of new orders, new money from Russia and from abroad," he said.
The market has been rallying since before Christmas and relatively low liquidity has put sharp upward pressure on share prices. The RTS index closed at 186.94 on December 23.
Leading shares have risen two to three percent since Friday and some second-tier oil companies made stronger gains as investors and operators searched for undervalued shares.
Second tier shares showed the strongest growth for the day, following a slowdown in rises among leading shares.
Operators said investors had begun to look away from the most liquid stocks to find relatively undervalued bargains.
St Petersburg International Telephone jumped to $2.75 at the close from $2.35 on Friday and Gazprom rose to $0.490 from $0.409.
LUKoil rose to $14.23 from $13.62, Norilsk Nickel to $6.28 from $5.95 and UES jumped to $0.1520 from $0.1385.
